qas.question: What is an effect of using worn molds when casting records?
What is the expected finish of a vinyl record?
What is the effect on a copy if a master as an orange peel effect?
On what frequencies is an orange peel effect most noticeable?
What material is on a direct metal mastering disc?

context: <a0_0>The "orange peel" effect<a0_0/> on vinyl records is caused by worn molds. Rather than having the proper <a1_0>mirror-like<a1_0/> finish, the surface of the record will have a texture that looks like orange peel. This introduces noise into the record, particularly in the <a3_0>lower frequency range<a3_0/>. With direct metal mastering (DMM), the master disc is cut on a <a4_0>copper<a4_0/>-coated disc, which can also have a minor "orange peel" effect on the disc itself. As this "orange peel" originates in the master rather than being introduced in the pressing stage, <a2_0>there is no ill effect<a2_0/> as there is no physical distortion of the groove.
